chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: In this problem, we will use the normal distribution property of a spreadsheet program to solve for the probability that we will lose money when investing in large company stocks.

To solve this problem, we first need to get the arithmetic mean and the standard deviation for large-company stocks. In this case, the values are:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Arithmetic mean}&=12.0\%\\
\text{Standard deviation}&=19.9\%
\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have these values, we will use $0\%$ as our expected return since we are looking at the probability of losing money. 

We will then click on an empty cell in the spreadsheet program, click on **"Insert formula"** then type **NORMDIST**.

Once you have pressed enter, you will be prompted to type the values needed.

Another to do this is by typing $=\text{NORM.DIST()}$ or $=\text{NORMDIST()}$ in the cell.

Inside the parentheses, we will enter the values in this order:

$$\begin{aligned}
&=\text{NORMDIST}(\text{expected value},\text{mean},\text{standard dev},\text{true})
\end{aligned}$$

In the case of this problem, we will enter this:
$$\begin{aligned}
&=\text{NORMDIST}(0,12,19.9,\text{true})
\end{aligned}$$
After pressing enter, the value will immediately show. In this case, the probability is $0.2732$ or $27.32\%$ chance that you will lose money at any year when investing in large-company stocks.
